verses.text: The Lord created man from the earth, and turned him back to it again.
verses.comment: This verse recalls the creation of Adam and humanity’s return to dust, stressing our dependence on God and mortality. See also Gen. 2:7, 3:19.

verses.text: He gave them a set number of days and a fixed time, and gave them authority over the things on the earth.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty gives us both limits and dignity. Human authority over creation foreshadows deeper spiritual responsibility.

verses.text: He endowed them with strength like his own, and made them in his own image.
verses.comment: Being made in God's image gives all human life sacred worth. The reference anticipates the restoration of this image in Christ. See Gen. 1:27.

verses.text: He gave them the ability to rule over all things, and put all things under their authority.
verses.comment: This dominion shows the role of humans as stewards reflecting the Creator’s kingship, underlying both a royal and priestly role.

verses.text: He gave them tongue, eyes, ears, and a heart to think.
verses.comment: The human faculties are gifts for knowing and praising God, indicating that awareness of truth is central to God’s design.

verses.text: He filled them with knowledge and understanding, and showed them good and evil.
verses.comment: Moral understanding is a divine endowment. The capacity for discernment points to God's law as a guide for life.

verses.text: He put his eye in their hearts, to show them the majesty of his works.
verses.comment: Inner awareness of God’s glory is universal, comparable to natural law (cf. Rom. 1:19).

verses.text: They will praise his holy name, to declare the greatness of his works.
verses.comment: True wisdom leads to worship, showing humanity’s vocation to praise God.

verses.text: He gave them knowledge, and allotted them a share in the law of life.
verses.comment: "Law of life" here refers to divine instruction, a source of blessing—see Deut. 30.

verses.text: He made an everlasting covenant with them, and revealed his decrees to them.
verses.comment: Covenant highlights God’s enduring promise and relationship with his people. The concept of covenant ties Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: Their eyes saw his glorious majesty, and their ears heard the glory of his voice.
verses.comment: This refers especially to the theophanies at Sinai and in the prophets. Divine glory and voice also anticipate Christ’s incarnation and the Transfiguration.

verses.text: He said to them, ‘Beware of all unrighteousness;’ and he gave each man commandments concerning his neighbor.
verses.comment: Moral law is universally given with a focus on justice and love of neighbor.

verses.text: Their ways are always before him; they will not be hidden from his eyes.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience is a comfort and a warning—He knows all our actions and thoughts.

verses.text: Every nation he appointed a ruler; but Israel is the Lord’s own portion.
verses.comment: While God governs all, he sets his special affection and election on his chosen people.

verses.text: All their works are as the sun before him, and his eyes are always upon their ways.
verses.comment: Nothing escapes God’s attention; there is a poetic emphasis on God’s ever-watching care.

verses.text: Their iniquities are not hidden from him, and all their sins are before the Lord.
verses.comment: God’s perfect justice demands accountability. Secret sins are ever before Him, highlighting the need for true repentance.

verses.text: But the Lord, being gracious, knows all their works, and does not reject them nor forsake them, but spares them.
verses.comment: Divine mercy balances God’s justice. This verse hints at the continual offer of forgiveness contingent upon repentance.

verses.text: The prayers of the humble reach to the clouds; he is comforted in their affliction.
verses.comment: Humility in prayer is especially pleasing to God (cf. Luke 18). God’s closeness to the contrite is a theme throughout Scripture.

verses.text: He will not overlook the prayer of the orphan, or the widow when she pours out her complaint.
verses.comment: God's concern for the vulnerable (widows, orphans) shows the social dimension of righteousness.

verses.text: Do not the tears of the widow run down her cheek as she cries out against him who has caused them to fall?
verses.comment: God sees the suffering and cries of the afflicted; justice will come for those who cause hardship.

verses.text: He who serves God wholeheartedly will be accepted, and his prayer reaches to the clouds.
verses.comment: Wholehearted devotion is key to acceptable prayer—faith and works are united here.

verses.text: The prayer of the humble pierces the clouds; until it arrives he is not comforted, and he will not withdraw until the Most High sees and judges justly, and executes justice.
verses.comment: Persistence in prayer is commended. God’s justice is sure, though not always immediate.

verses.text: And the Lord will not delay, neither will he be patient with them, until he crushes the loins of the merciless and repays vengeance on the nations;
verses.comment: God’s justice also includes retribution for the unrepentant and oppressors.

verses.text: until he takes away the multitude of the proud, and breaks the scepters of the unrighteous;
verses.comment: God reverses worldly power. The theme anticipates the Magnificat (Luke 1:52).

verses.text: until he renders to each man according to his deeds, and repays the works of men according to their intentions.
verses.comment: A clear teaching on accountability: God weighs not only actions but motives (see Matt. 16:27).

verses.text: He will judge the discussion of his people, and make them rejoice in his mercy.
verses.comment: Mercy is vividly linked with judgment. God’s mercy triumphs, foreshadowing Christ’s ministry (see Jas. 2:13).

verses.text: Those who repent he allows to return, and he strengthens those who lack perseverance.
verses.comment: God’s mercy is open to all who repent; this anticipates the parable of the Prodigal Son.

verses.text: Return to the Lord, and forsake your sins; pray before his face and lessen your offenses.
verses.comment: Repentance is an ongoing return—a lived conversion, not a one-time decision.

verses.text: Turn back to the Most High, and turn away from injustice, and hate abominations intensely.
verses.comment: Repentance requires interior conversion—hating sin is as important as loving good. See Rom. 12:9.

verses.text: Who will praise the Most High in the grave, instead of the living and those who give thanks?
verses.comment: There is urgency in conversion—only the living can give God true praise.

verses.text: From the dead, as from one who does not exist, thanksgiving has ceased; he who is alive and well will praise the Lord.
verses.comment: There is a call to live gratefully and laud God in this life—earthly praise unites us with the righteous.

verses.text: How great is the mercy of the Lord, and his forgiveness to those who turn to him!
verses.comment: Divine mercy and forgiveness are always available. The focus on repentance and mercy is reflected in Jesus' teaching—confession and contrition remain foundational for reconciliation with God.
